Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Neuroendocrine and Behavioral Responses to Witnessing a Dominance Contest: Insights from the 2012 Presidential Election

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Status hierarchies are ubiquitous across human and animal societies, and dominance contests are an important means for determining status in social groups. These contests include physical confrontations - fights, sports matches, and even wars -- as well as non-physical competitions, such as competitive exams, job interviews, and formal presentations. Although previous research has examined face-to-face dominance contests, little is known about the biosocial processes involved in large-scale societal dominance contests such as democratic elections. Given the widespread significance of presidential elections for the actual and perceived status of nearly all society members, it is critical for social psychology researchers to study them to build more comprehensive theories of status hierarchies. Bringing together theories and empirical approaches in behavioral neuroendocrinology and social-personality psychology, the aim of this proposal is to examine voters' neuroendocrine and behavioral dynamics before, during, and after the 2012 US presidential election.

The proposed research is focused around three broad empirical questions: (1) what are the psychological factors that explain variation in hormone responses (testosterone and cortisol) among eligible voters, (2) what are the behavioral consequences of these hormone response profiles (e.g., changes in aggressive behavior and prosocial behavior), and (3) what is the temporal trajectory of neuroendocrine and behavioral responses to the election? To address these questions, the proposed study will recruit healthy men and women who are registered to vote and hold views across the political spectrum. On five theoretically-relevant days (two days prior to the election, election day, and two days after the election), participants will provide saliva samples to measure diurnal testosterone and cortisol in order to assess hormone responses to the results of the presidential election. Participants will also wear an iPod Touch with Electronically Activated Software (EAR) to record naturally occurring social interactions and behaviors via short audio clips. Daily diaries and surveys will be collected throughout the study. Participants will be requested to release social media feeds in the weeks surrounding the election. Finally, public voting information will be accessed to confirm whether or not participants voted in the election.

This proposal breaks new ground in examining hormone-behavior associations in a real-world dominance contest. While previous work has shown that observer's steroid hormone levels can fluctuate when witnessing a dominance contest, little is known about (a) the behavioral consequences of observers hormone changes and (b) the psychological factors that explain variability in these hormone responses. The proposed work also addresses the onset and trajectories of hormonal and behavioral changes before, during, and after a high-stakes societal dominance contest.

This project has implications for theories of individual and group-based dominance hierarchies across multiple fields, including psychology, behavioral neuroendocrinology, neuroscience, political science, sociology, and anthropology. Moreover, this research will serve as a training foundation in social neuroendocrinology research for students from underrepresented groups. Finally, the proposed work has implications for at least two public policy issues. Specifically, the findings are expected to assist in devising new interventions to (1) curb aggression and violence in individual and group-based status hierarchies, and (2) decrease stress and improve health in individuals and groups who perceive themselves as low status. The data and analytical approach may also reveal strategies for increasing enthusiasm and positive affect to improve voter turnout in democratic elections.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Status hierarchies are ubiquitous across human and animal societies. High status within social hierarchies confers benefits that promote survival and reproduction, including privileged access to limited resources (money, food, mates), greater power and influence over subordinates, and improved health. Because of these many benefits, individuals are often motivated to gain and maintain high social rank over others. In fact, theorists have argued that the drive for status is one of the most fundamental human motives. Dominance contests are an important means for determining status in social groups. These include physical confrontations - fights, sports matches, and even wars – as well as non-physical competitions, such as competitive exams, job interviews, and formal presentations. Although previous research has provided initial clues about the social and biological factors that modulate behavior in face-to-face dominance contests (e.g., sports matches, laboratory-based competitions), very little is known about the biosocial processes involved in large-scale societal dominance contests such as democratic elections. Not only does winning or losing an election affect the social status of the candidates themselves, but presidential elections in particular likely affect the perceived status and well-being of all citizens, whose civil rights and quality of life are influenced by the policies and laws enacted by the president. Given the widespread significance of presidential elections for the actual and perceived status of nearly all society members, it is critical for social psychological researchers to study them when possible in order to build more comprehensive theories of individual- and group-based status hierarchies. Bringing together theories and empirical approaches in behavioral neuroendocrinology and social-personality psychology, this project investigates voters’ neuroendocrine, psychological, and behavioral dynamics before, during, and after the 2012 US presidential election (November 6, 2012), a high-stakes political event that occurs only once every four years.

We recruited 113 voters -- 33 Republicans, 62 Democrats, and 18 undecided voters -- representative of the demographics of Eugene, OR to participate in the study. Participants provided 25 saliva samples each for the 3 weeks surrounding Election Day to measure changes in hormones implicated in dominance motivation (testosterone) and psychological stress (cortisol). Changes in psychological states and political attitudes were captured through automated text messaging, daily diary reporting, and online surveys. Everyday behavior was tracked unobtrusively through an iPod Touch application that recorded brief audio clips as participants went about their daily lives. Participants’ online social behaviors were tracked through Facebook and Twitter posts. Public voting records were also consulted. Finally, a follow-survey was conducted 6 months after Election Day to examine whether biological responses to the election outcome produced long-lasting changes in psychological states, political attitudes, and social behavior.

Republicans rose in testosterone after Obama was declared the winner: Prior research shows that the outcome of any competition (i.e. victory or loss) is associated with changes in testosterone, especially in males. In our study, we found that male Republicans rose in testosterone compared to male Democrats after Obama was declared winner on election night. These findings suggest that male Republicans may have experienced heightened dominance and competitive motivation, as reflected in their higher testosterone levels. We are currently analyzing psychological and behavioral data to test this prediction.
